I'm about as hairy as many trans women, with broad shoulders and an unwanted dimple in my chin, so I can somewhat imagine that strange feeling of discomfort in your own skin Of course, as a cis woman I'll never know what actual gender dsyphoria feels like, but at least I can relate to a small degree with how paniced and helpless and _wrong_ your body can make you feel :/

'don't you feel like a woman?' 'No, I feel like myself.' 'well, exactly.'  I have someone close to me who is an FtM transgender person, and for two years I've been researching it and trying to figure out exactly what that means.  I can understand being unsure of your own identity, or even having an identity crisis and not understanding your psychology, your emotions, your desires, your feelings, your interests, your behavioral impulses, etc. As a man, I can even understand feeling feminine (i.e. having interests and mannerisms that are typically associated with females rather than males, that are regarded as feminine rather than masculine).  But is that all FtM trans people mean when they say that they feel like they're 'women in a man's body'? I get the impression that it's more than that: they also claim to 'feel' that they are of the opposite sex, not just the opposite gender.   What I can't understand is 'feeling' female (or male, for that matter). Sure, having an erection, and having sex as a male 'feels' a certain way, and that experience is not available to females. And I'm sure that having breasts and a vagina allows for certain experiences that are not available to males. So I can definitely understand that males and females have different sexual experiences. But is that all that is meant by 'I feel like I am in a male body' or 'I feel like I am in a female body'? Again, I don't think so.   As the video demonstrates, trans people also claim to feel something like dysmorphia: they feel that they shouldn't have the secondary sex characteristics that are typical of their sex at birth, and that their body should be morphologically similar to the other sex. For example, FtM trans people worry about hair loss, the size of their hands, their height, the width of their shoulders, the size of their head, the depth of their voice, facial hair, general body hair - I understand that they also feel that their penis shouldn't be there, so much so that some even try to cut it off themselves.  This is what's so confusing, I think: it doesn't 'feel' like anything in particular to have less hair, to have wide shoulders, to have a hairy body. These are not things you feel and are normally aware of, unless you consciously think about these things (even then, you can only concentrate on them, there is no 'feeling' or sensation associated with the length of your hair, width of shoulders, etc.). It doesn't 'feel' like anything in particular to have a male body (a body with male secondary sex characteristics), and I have a very hard time believing that females can 'feel' what it's like to have a female body (a body with female secondary sex characteristics).  So I simply cannot understand: what does it feel like to 'be' of a certain sex, let alone of the opposite sex? Do trans people simply wish they had the sexual experiences of the other sex, rather than the sexual experiences that they currently have?   And it's still not entirely clear to me what it 'feels' like to 'be' of a certain gender: does it mean that you have say feminine interests, behaviors, and mannerisms? But what counts as 'feminine' is simply what is the norm for women, and just because some interests/behaviors/mannerisms/etc. are the norm for women doesn't mean that every woman has them - there are butch women, tomboys, etc. who are no less 'women' for having interests/behaviors/mannerisms/feelings/etc. that are not typical for women. In fact, when people say 'woman', I don't think they mean 'someone who has the interests/behaviors/mannerisms/feelings/etc. typical of females and other persons with the gender role of 'woman' ', I think they mean something much closer to 'female'. So when an FtM trans person says 'I feel like a woman in a man's body', I don't understand: do you mean to say that you feel like a biological female with female-typical interests/behaviors/mannerisms/etc. inside a biologically male body? That's incomprehensible to me, because I don't understand what it means to 'feel like a biological male (or female)'. Do you mean to say that you feel that you should have the sexual experiences of the opposite sex? I can sort of understand that, though I have a hard time understanding how one could imagine what it feels like to experience sexual intercourse as the opposite sex, and to specifically want that experience (I could understand though if you DON'T want the sexual experiences of your own sex, because you've experienced them already, and you might not like them). Do you mean to say that you feel that your interests/behaviors/mannerisms/feelings/etc. are more typical of the other sex, so you identify with members of the other sex because you feel that your personality is more similar to them than to members of your own sex? But then, why not say you're just non-binary, or even just say that you are cis-gendered but you don't have all the typical personality traits that are typical of your gender?   I simply don't understand what they mean. So when I heard that little piece of dialogue ('don't you feel like a woman?' 'No, I feel like myself.' 'well, exactly.'), that made absolutely no sense to me. I don't know what it's supposed to mean to 'feel like a woman',  and the 'well exactly' raises even more questions. What does it mean?

Boring white cishet here. I'm so sorry you feel like this (felt, maybe, since you seem to be well on your way through transitioning a year later). I have a trans friend on facebook, and I care about her a lot, and I know she's been through more than any fuckwit she's ever met (including me), and she posts things ENDING IN ALL CAPS that wind up alienating many of her friends. It was hard for me to sympathize completely with her because of that well earned bitterness, and even though every trans experience is different, your video makes me feel a little closer to what she went through in a way she perhaps couldn't express. I suppose you dont read comments ContraPoints-- I don't think I would, as a YouTube creator,  and you have more than enough to read as is, but I wanted, to, I guess, put forth some energy into the universe, or perhaps something someone else could read, or perhaps I am being , as most poets like myself are wont to be, a little self masturbatory, and enamored with my own writing.  I hope that isn't what this is.   I have spent this evening watching a good chunk of your videos, and I only wanted to say that you are appreciated and respected immensely here. Not only for your political and philosophical work  (which, I have to say is bomb as shit? the exchange of free information to better the world is, to say the least, one of the virtues of youtube that can challenge its vices, and thank you for doing something I could never do) but- as an artist, a person with immense creative worth, and what's more, as a person.   I don't know you, and perhaps the sort-of-late hour combined with the sudden influx of your content has given me a false sense of camaraderie, but there was so much of your content that struck me deep in my gut, the kind of place that is, at this point, kind of hard to reach? I feel- honestly kind of honored to have come across your work, and to have spent my time learning from your content. I'm a 19 year old complete dumbass too pompous for my own good, but. Damn if I don't think you have something good here.  So, again. Thank you, and thank you for sharing your thoughts and content.

Although I doubt I will ever experience the amount of gender dysphoria it takes to go motivate going through any sort of surgery I have my stints with it (for instance: I hate my hairy legs and never wears shorts, even when it's a million degrees outside, and shaving is too much of a hassle with the stubble and rashes and people starting to call you a fag so I don't bother). If I toy with the idea of one day for some reason I would wake up as a woman (and the different hormone levels didn't radically change how I behave) I THINK I would pretty much shrug and move on with my life much like I already do (after furiously masturbating for a few days with the new found parts off course). Getting rid of my body completely and live just as a consciousness is an idea far more appealing than change this fleshy shell I was born into. I have already lived most of life inside my own head and often feel eating and sleeping is a hassle with the having to interact with the outside world and everything. So transhumanism and the singularity would be the ideal thing for me I guess, too bad it's still just science fiction or science in it's infancy. ANYWAY, I had too much coffee, this was great.

My brother is trans....so I guess my....sister now? I love him/her to death, I really do, but I'm still not sure how to deal with it. I'm bi, so you'd think I could relate, but I'd hate to say I really don't get it at all. For a long time I thought being trans was a mental illness, and sort of still do. I can get him being gay (which he is, by his own admission), because people like to fuck, have different tastes, and there's plenty of evidence suggesting that it's largely genetic (I think I can attest to that firsthand), and even him being more effeminate because, I mean who gives a fuck if he prefers painting his nails to playing football?  But I just don't get why someone would go to such great lengths to make themselves the opposite sex, or actually believe themselves to be it. I mean if you want to dress up and shit, fine. But to me there's a world of difference between that and 'I want to cut my dick off and swap it out for a non-functioning pussy'. He wants to transition, do the surgery and all that once he gets the money. As someone who wants to be a father, it just seems nonsensical and unnatural to me, even morally wrong in a sense, to give up your ability to have kids, or even get off, (no offense to you, but can you? Have you actually transitioned yet? I've heard the alternate sex organ they give you can't do that anymore) because he feels a certain way and might change his mind later. I mean....will he? How hardwired is this, and if you've transitioned, have you ever regretted your decision? This probably seems like a lot of questions, and I probably seem like a narrow-minded ass. But I'd most likely just say something that offends him or starts a fight if I tried being this blunt with him about how I felt.   As someone who seems like you could understand being in his situation, and possibly even mine, could you give me a bit of advice?

I'm so obsessed with this gender conversation. I'm genetically a female, but I don't conform to societal concepts of femininity. I'm bisexual, but I'm straight passing. My partner is a straight man who is much more feminine than I am in many regards. I'm afraid to call myself anything other than a woman. I can control my internal conflict though much easier than I can control outer conflict caused by me coming out . . . again. I came out as bi to my family and admitted that I am an agnostic during a discussion. I just don't want to deal with it. So instead, I'll try to challenge people's idea of what women are supposed to be by being myself. My uncomfortably masculine self. Besides, my depression is basically my most dominant personality trait anyway.

Rude but earnest questions: Why do you see yourself as a trans woman rather than as a feminine male? What's so important about claiming the word 'woman' or believing in the idea of a transition? Even if you were to frame it as a male with a so-called 'feminized brain' wouldn't that still be fundamentally a male? Why adopt the gender binary for self-definition when you can be free of it and not have to artificially invade a sex class you do not belong to? Aren't you really just trying to bend reality to fit an idea it can't really fit because one cannot change their sex just their gender presentation? Wouldn't it be more non-conformist to admit your sex class but refuse to behave according to it's gendered expectations? Why don't you believe in learning to love your body as is without having to make radical changes to it? Why is it so important that you fit people's expectations of what you should be, such as  the issue with having a feminine voice rather than practicing and cultivating self-acceptance?  What's wrong with keeping your voice as is and looking feminine? Don't you think there's something wrong with caring so much what others think? I don't feel that your video clarifies any of this.

I've been looking into ethics and I kept going 'hang on a minute - this is all in Terminator 2!' - so I've been going back to that movie (watched a great 60 min presentation by 'Industry Workshops' on YoutTube from 11 months ago - gave me an overview of myths, story telling, visual narrative, and character arcs, but also how to engage lower and higher brain functions).   I started off with the stanford prison experiment (and the BBC re-run in 2002, which went differently but still ended up with tyranny). Then moved onto to Ethics of Care versus Ethics of Justice (Gilligan vs Kohlberg) and naturally went from that to thinking off a female mental institution experiment versus the male stanford prison experiment - thinking about Empathy and Relationships versus Power and Entitlement.... Things that feature in Terminator 2 (but is not represented in Sarah Connor's mental institution as a place of Empathy in contrast to the Stanford Prison Experiment as a place of Power - as Sarah's mental institution is shown as being no different to a Prison in that sense). Ethics of Care vs Ethics of Justice get chracterized along gendered lines - so maybe it's not a real distinction or it's platitudes ect?   I had already been researching gender identity in the brain though, which seemed to be down to a dominance of the Bed Nucleus of the Stria Terminalis (BNST) in the 'reptilian' brain in males (driving masculine aggression and favouring action) as a result of oxytocin receptors in the BNST (that are fewer in females in the BNST) versus more reliance on the limbic cortex in the brains of females (allowing for more emotional cognition). These findings, if correct, are controversial because it would indicate that men are more adapted to deal with physical stress than women. And also that women have more of an ability to deal with emotional stress (the stereotype of the male flying of the handle with aggression when things go wrong versus the calmer female who tries to work through a problem)... These features of the brain appear swapped over in transgender individuals. I am not an expert though.   ...I've thought about this in terms of feminism and concluded that the goal of feminism should be to improve male and female mental health (regularly being aggressive reduces grey matter in the brain and leads to psychosis). The problem is that the BNST via oxytocin ties into social identity (mental memory and also muscle memory) - literally gender identity. So feminism requires more than just altering social constructs of gender but to succeed requirest males to compromise their prefered mode of being - something a gentleman should already be able to do.   As the BNST is less active in females (removing the BNST in males leads to more feminine type behaviour) I am less certain of where female gender identity arises from as it seems not a simple case of attributing it to the BNST (so called what causes transgenderism). However, new research indicates that memories form in mutliple areas of the brain at once to be later intergrated together to reinforce a memory. So it could be that females reliance on higher brain regions compared to males could be where the female gender identity resides? - as all memories require oxytocin, which is a social hormone.   Males do have more grey matter in their BNST and Amygdalae than females, whereas as females tend to have a thicker layer of grey matter in their cerebral cortex than males (also reflected in scans of transgender brains). Though this finding is complicated by the way grey matter converts to white matter in the process of 'trimming' as we develop - white matter being faster established neural connections developing from repeated activity. So it could be that in the case of the right hemisphere - relating to physical activity - in which this is more evident, that females just have untapped potential? But then isn't hemisphere activity related to amygdalae activity, which is more dominant on the right side in males - this also relates to sexuality as in homosexuals dominance of the left or right amygdala is swapped over. But then sexuality and gender identity are different (as you get homosexual trans men and women). White matter seems more important for sexuality (including peadophilia) - maybe the key to gender identity is in the grey matter (e.g. amount in different regions of the brain)? - both in the 'reptilian' brain and the cerebral cortex?

What is the 'Boon' for transgender people? I'm sure everyone is familiar with Star Wars - it was influenced a lot by Joseph Cambell's 'Monomyth', which was a generalised story arc of the Hero's/Heroine's Journey based on his observations of all the similarities of myths throughout the history of human cultures.   The 'Boon' is the goal or objective for the proganonist - such as destroying the Death Star for example...  The 'boon' is generally an achievement of both individual attainment and recognition by peers and a journey into adulthood generally as a respected member.   The Monomyth has three distinct sections: SEPARATION, INITIATION, and RETURN. Between each section is an event that creates a threshold moment - between Separation and Initiation Luke's aunt and uncle are murdered; between Initiation and Return Obi-Wan scarficies himself.   I think quite often for Transgender people there is a lot of pressure to 'stay on the farm' and get 'killed' by a Psychiatrist/Pyschologist Stormtrooper working within the system to prevent the transition from Separation to Initiation for the Transgender person - i.e. conform (die either spiritually or literally).  Obviously a problem is you can only get the 'Boon' if you play by the systems rules - if transgender people aren't even allowed to have the 'Boon' then how can they be part of the franchise?  Those who are lucky (or geniuses) or fight hard enough to tear themselves away from the ties that bind or just reach absolute breaking point between life and death, can find their own meaning in life and in a way that encompasses the human spirit - this may mean finding a higher purpose beyond the veil of the franchise and the system...   easier with the help of a mentor which is usually an experienced transgender person or transgender collective (their Obi-Wan) who knows how to get the system to work for transgender people. I should explain that I have been attacked by a persistent TERF for about a month now on and off, and I ended up calling her a 'social darwinist'. I thought I'd read a bit more about the term and came across an unexpected link with 'Monism' and I though 'hmmm... don't I have monist views about cosmology?'. It is difficult for me to define exactly how I view the universe, but anyway I was more in favour of string theory over the multiverse theory (even though this theory makes sense in terms of quantum physics - 'everything that can happen does happen'). I guess I am a bit of a perfectionist, and I know that is bad for not just transphobia but viewing human beings in general. I also rejected descartes mind dualism... so does that mean I'm a monist - fuck? I'm a bastard. But hang on... There's existence pluralism (or priority plurism..  I have no idea), but basically the 'universe' in a monist view would have the cosmos made up of just one 'verse' or 'song'. Whereas as a multiverse would have 'multi-verses' or 'multi-songs' - perhaps infinitely many, like infinitely many ripples on a pond combining together...  that is actually more how I see the cosmos. I still think there is only one univese but I think it is made up of many verses combined (in a way much more abstract than the multiverse hypothesis - like the quantum approach.... it's just all in the maths). So I guess I hold a pluralistic view. But I hadn't really considered if how I view existence was affecting how I viewed everything else. I guess maybe it could help being less of a perfectionist? Maybe I need to also think about how I view the mind as well. That TERF is still at me...   I'm just going to ignore her because she won't accept defeat.

Great video!  Changing the body to match the mind, or changing the mind to accept the body.  Is either more or less ethical depending on what the person wants?  But changing the body to match the mind using hormones also changes the mind.  I wonder if the bulk of suffers (if that is an appropriate term) of gender dysphoria would suffer it, if generalized gendered social expectations were different from what they are now.  But aren't those expectations, if they are really expectations in the current zeitgeist, built on generalized norms of behavioral characteristics that extend beyond social input and have a biological foundation?  I would think the biological foundation of gendered expectations would find strong evidence in the existence of gender dysphoria.  As in, (while there is much gray area in personality and behavior between the biological sexes) do males with gender dysphoria ever fit a stereotypical male behavioral template and vise versa or do they usually exhibit the behaviors of the other sex?    As a side note, I have caught on that there seem to be multiple meanings for sex and gender, while they are interchangeable have usually meant physical biology but also mean something different from physical genetic expression to encompass something different.  As in gender dysphoria, to my understanding, means to feel dysphoria about your genitals not who you are as a person (more masculine vs. feminine).  It seems that our feeling that we are a something in the driver's seat of a body, looking out from behind the eyes leads us to the belief that we are something more than our bodies.  That the mind has a sense of permanence that the body doesn't.  The same mechanism that gives most the belief in a soul or afterlife or reincarnation.  Therefore changing the body is of no consequence, where changing the mind would feel like changing the person into a different person.  It is near impossible to imagine changing the only thing you know, yourself.  Where the record of your changing body over time through age is there to see, the change in your mind through age can prove to be more elusive.  However, changing the mind to accept the body might not create a major change in personality, perhaps only a lining up of mind and body leaving the personality intact.

Thank you SO much for making this.  In my teens / early twenties, I struggled with gender identity.  I was born male, but didn't consider myself masculine, and in fact found most hyper-masculine behaviour to be repellent and scary.  I dabbled with transvestism, and found some sense in privately presenting as female, but never felt comfortable enough to take it public.  I'm in my late 30s now; I've made huge strides in reconciling my own masculine and feminine sides, and am happy identifying as male, even while there's still a 'female' part of me which goes unexpressed.  And, honestly, I've no idea *who* I would be now if I'd been exposed to the idea of transgenderism when I was younger.  All this to say: thank you thank you thank you for sharing your personal experience (and so entertainingly at that).  Thank you for standing up to be seen and heard, which is the first step to being understood.  Thank you for starting conversations and introspections.  And best of luck on your journey.

You know, this video isn't just being funny, entertaining and honest for the sake of a YouTube video. It's much more; this video is amazing. As someone who doesn't have any gender dysmorphia (that I know of at least, I'm the opposite of who you think of when you imagine 'perfectly normal and well-balanced' so it may play a role. I personally doubt it though for some reason) I can say that this really helps me understand what it must be like, even if I can never truly understand the full implications of the problem on someone who's going through/has gone through it. I think it might sound stupid at first, but I think the highest praise I can possibly give to a work such as this is: I get it. I understand now in a way that I didn't before. Thank you for broadening my empathetic vocabulary.  On a technical note, the video was done well. Most shots had a nice fore, middle, and background, but cleverly choosing to change that for the hallucination. The shots were symmetrical and visually pleasing or interesting for the most part, and this also had a sense of color and life that's rarely seen anymore (well, maybe you see it a lot on YouTube, but it feels fake, dishonest and usually disorganized with colors that don't match or convey a feeling that fits with the video, or some other reason. Take your pick, there's a million of them) It was more like the breadth and life of an Alejandro Jodorowski film. Plus, it had some very obvious, as well as some really subtle moments that were influenced by other great filmmakers and other artists. I now see your creative vision, and when I have disposable income, I imagine myself giving you money of patreon.  I do really hope that you do more content like this though. This was masterful Impressionism, excellent use of color, great placing and decent blocking, original ideas and methods of conveying feelings that need to be better understood, and so much more that can't be quantified from my critical perspective.      Incase my review of a YouTube video, (I know, a review of a YouTube video. Regardless of how good the video is, that's unquantifiably pathetic as a critic) here's the td;lr: Great video, watch it to get a better understanding of dysmorphia. Give money to Contrapoints.

when I was anorexic I used to keep journals with calorie numbers....I would use bracelets to make sure my upper arms were thin enough to fit what would fit around an average persons wrist.  I had certain rituals I would do every day to measure certain parts of my body. eg I decided my shoulders were too disproportionately big compared to the rest of my body. I failed exams due to checking these measurements and spent hours in the mirror going over these insane things...so ashamed that people would think i was vain...even though i hated myself. The more starved I got the more distorted my perception was. in hind sight...there was nothing abnormal about me. I Know Th is isn't the same as gender dysphoria...but I can relate so much to this video. For me it wasn't about fearing being the wrong gender...but being a woman as opposed to a girl. Having curves...having Boobs....which I used to flatten to make me less womanly. It was about staying a child. And believing that if I looked like one I wasn't sexually provocative.  It wasn't conscious. I just felt safer that way. I love you Contra. I hope these feelings ease AA they have for me

It took me a long time to be more open-minded. Well, I never considered myself to be conservative but I had trouble understanding people with gender dysphoria and let's say I didn't have the nicest view on them. I wanted to understand though. It's obviously something a lot of people experience. And I started thinking... what if someone took away my identity from me? What if I didn't feel like a woman at all? What if everytime I saw myself in the mirror I thought I couldn't really change and morph my body into what I wanted it to be no matter how hard I tried? And then the realisation hit me. This video helped me grasp the subject even better.  I'm really glad you're making these kinds of videos, Contra! I hope they reach as many people as possible. The effort you put into your videos always amazes me. The humor, the raw emotion, the empathy... They are very 'human' in nature if I can express myself that way. I just wish more people had your approach when it comes to making videos. Keep making great stuff like this!  I'm sorry for my clumsy English, it's not my first language : )

Even as a supporter and empathizer, I know I can never understand what goes on inside the mind of a trans person, not being trans myself, but I think I got a small insight. When I saw the 'why do I have hair here?' part I had tears in my eyes because I have a lot of hair in places no human should have hair (shaft and foreskin if you're wondering), and being a person of color, as a child i always felt it's because my ethnic group was inferior, less evolved, and are 'closer to animals'. It took me a long time to get myself out of that thinking. Still hate the hair though. :)   We are all disappointed with our bodies in some ways, but your video makes me think that gender dysphoria is all that disappointment on steroids and LSD, and all of it is perceived as how it takes away your body from its true gender. Good Lord, the cycle of being reminded of the flaws, depression, and forgetting long enough to be happy must be tiring. Too tiring. I've experienced some of that.  It must have been cathartic to point them out in public, instead of keeping them hidden.   I really don't know how to deal with my own body issues...I'm just hoping to find someone who actually LIKES the errors of my body. Maybe only then I can let go of it. I'm hoping the same for you. We should find imperfect people whose imperfections we can truly love, and maybe they are quite ok and even like our imperfections.

Wow, Contra. I've been a big fan of your channel for a while now, but you've really outdone yourself with this one. I know you're probably not comfortable thinking of yourself this way, but this video is so unbelievably brave. You're really opening yourself up to your viewers and followers and Cthulhu knows who else and that must feel quite scary. I can imagine you putting all the work into this video and hovering over the upload button and wondering 'Am I really okay with sharing this?' Maybe you're not, but I would surely be terrified. I just wanted to thank you for the work that you do.   I'm trying to avoid being a weird man on the internet saying that he loves you, but your work connects deeply with me, and there are a lot of people out here in the shit-aether that is the Youtube commentariat who don't presume to be your friend, but have come to genuinely care about you, and who want you to feel if not happy, then at least comfortable with yourself. You're a special person, and you've enriched the lives of so many of us, to the point that seeing you cry is physically painful to me and chokes me up.  And you're goddamned beautiful to boot! Keep on being such a magnificent weirdo, and know that your work inspires people who try to fight transphobia and misogyny and homophobia and bigotry all the time on a ground level of one conversation at a time. Wherever you choose to take your channel, and however you evolve in terms of your identity, I'll be there, rooting for you.  <3  Brad

This hit much harder than I expected. As someone who by and large has to behave and present as a male, and who has experienced tons of Gender Dysphoria, I can relate to pretty much every single scene. I know what it's like to try on outfit after outfit, makeup, and everything else I can think of only to look in the mirror and see the most obviously masculine features. I know what it's like to despise the hair on my body which grows so quickly. I know what it's like to be rejected and made to feel worthless for being unable to be sexual with partners because of that. The part that hit the most home, as a singer and musician, was where you sat in front of the microphone discussing how your voice didn't sound feminine. That felt like it could've been me, to an exact tee. My voice is actually probably the worst, come to think of it... it's impossible to feel like I will ever be who I want, or express myself how I want. And all the people who tell me I should just do it or just be myself don't get that it isn't so much other's perception or their support or lack thereof that affects me, it's that I know that I cannot be in any way feminine convincingly, as much as I might want, least of all too myself. I...I don't know, I've rambled too much... this just hit me very hard... Thank you, Contra, this is one of the best representations I've ever seen describing how I, and I'm sure many others, experience Dysphoria.

I know I'm probably not the only boring trans(itioned) woman to tell you this, but I think you should give transition a serious try. So much of this BS that you've had like a ton of lead over you all your life ebbs away and you achieve a kind of calm you never thought you could have. I first took estro about 14 years ago and it was a revelation to me, all the emotional ill-fitting pieces just worked when I just let them sort out by themselves. Transitioning is not always pretty, but it allows you to become yourself and mostly (it takes time) forget about all the dysphoric nonsense. As for the voice.. I had (technically have) a baritone like you but I worked it into the voice I've been using for the last decade and a half and  I never have trouble passing. I even worked over the phone without a hitch. I still don't like my voice that much, and I really, really wish it was a pretty singing voice, but it works and goddamn it it's mine. It just takes some work to hit the right place, but when you do, it works like a charm. The training also allows you to extend your voice a ton. The website that helped me a ton in this regard (Amberspace) has since gone dead, but it's still on the wayback machine URL Sorry for the long post, but I quite enjoy your videos and wish you the best <3

You're so fucking beautiful. Thank you for making this. I don't have gender dysphoria and am pretty vanilla when it comes to my gender expression, but I do know what it's like to hate one's own body and to think, 'This can't be my body, this can't be real.' The last lyrics of the closing song, 'Is this even real,' really drove that home for me. I used to be 100 lbs at 5'4', and a professional art model. After a couple of years, my lifestyle of...indulgences...caused me to develop adult-onset, life-threatening asthma. The meds I needed for my asthma subsequently caused me to gain about 40 lbs over the course of 2 years. It was really traumatizing, I couldn't even get out of bed the first day I saw stretch marks on my body. The calls for modeling jobs waned, and then stopped entirely. I didn't even want to have sex anymore because all I could think about was how fat I looked to my partner (which is not what he thinks at all).  So...I'm not comparing it to gender dysphoria, but looking in the mirror and not being able to live with what's there...yeah, I get that 100%.

This is pure artistry. Pure expression leaping straight out of someone's soul. It's absolutely beautiful. Beautiful in that it conveys very uncomfortable feelings in a very artistic way. I will always say that I envy everyone with a platform upon which they can express their inner thoughts and ideas. I never really cultivated an artistic pursuit of my own, but you (Contrapoints) and many other artists have shown me that it's still possible. Seeing the development of your artistic expression grow over time has really inspired me.  About the video itself, I feel like I identify with some of this more than I've realized. I haven't experienced major dysphoria, but there's definitely a minor form of it I feel sometimes. I'm very uncomfortable with too much masculinity and I try to minimize it somewhat and exaggerate my more feminine traits to help balance it out. It's very striking seeing some of my own thoughts in this movie being expressed (even if they're to an extreme), and I feel like I understand dysphoria much more.  How would the general population see something like this? Hopefully they feel as uncomfortable as they were intended to feel, because it's all about delivering a subjective experience.   Anyway I basically love you, Contrapoints. This video is amazing. You're amazing. Keep doing more of whatever it is you do, please.

Hopefully without sounding too prescriptive here, because I'm really not trying to be, I think it would help alleviate some of the pain you're feeling to at least explore the possibility of HRT. There's a community on reddit for DIY HRT (/r/transDIY), so you don't even need a doctor, which I know you've said was one of the reasons you were avoiding it. And you don't need a 'full' dose. You can control it yourself as long as you're monitoring your own levels. And you don't even need to add estrogen, right away. You could take justan anti-androgen for a couple months and see how you feel without male testosterone levels before committing or not.  Maybe you'll discover that your brain likes testosterone better, after all, and it's just physical things, which can be changed, that are the source of your pain. Maybe you'll find that a more female hormonal balance is better for you psychologically. You won't know until you find out, right?  And with all that being said. I'm not saying 'change your body.' I'm saying that I empathize very, very strongly with the emotions in this video, and from both my own experiences as a trans person as well as countless other trans people's experiences, both binary and non-binary, HRT does *a lot.* It's not just about the physical changes, it touches something a little deeper than that, as well. Something less tangible but at the same time very visceral than body dysphoria.  And if it helps at all, your voice is already pretty androgynous. It really is. But if you did want to feminize it a little more, then I really don't think it would take you very long to train it if you followed a good guide. Another trans community on reddit (seriously you should spend some time exploring the trans subreddits, a lot of them are super great) is /r/transvoice. There are guides people have posted on how to help feminize your voice the right way. It takes some practice, but you're a at a great starting point already. I think you'd probably have pretty quick results in finding a voice you're more comfortable with.  Anyway. I've rambled enough and you probably won't read this. But if you do, know that there are a lot of people who know a lot of what you're going through right now. Don't shy away from the experiences of those who have been down that road before. You don't have to shoulder all this on your own. :)

This is so beautiful. Truly, everything about it, from the witty and honest script, the editing, the music, the gorgeous lighting, your outfits (that all-pink one in the strawberry eating sequence is so fucking good, my jaw dropped) - this an absolutely stellar piece of filmmaking. Thank you for being so courageously open and vulnerable on this way.   And I'm sorry that you've been struggling so much. As a trans person, I understand how fucking much dysphoria sucks. Everything you said here resonates with me so strongly.   It's my deep hope that you'll be able to see all the things that make you feel like less of a woman right now as more of one later on. You can be a woman with thinning hair, with body hair, with a deep voice, tall, with a dick - that's fine. None of those things define womanhood. And as a bigender fella that wants to be seen as more masculine, I get wanting to adjust your body and feeling such terrible guilt and shame when you can't be as malleable as you hope to be. But it's important to remember that gender is defined by us. We make it what we want.   All I'm trying to say, and probably failing at, is that I so deeply wish that you one day find peace in yourself, and love the magnificent woman as well as the wonderful man and all other forma of gender you may happen to be that you are. You are a brilliant mind and a creative soul before anything else. All my love.

I made this video based on personal experience. I didn't do any research for this one and instead opted to just like express myself. So my main goal is just to make art, but I also hope that depicting an individual experience of dysphoria in detail helps non-trans people understand it better.  I should say that this does not represent everyone's experience of gender dysphoria. AFAB (assigned female at birth) people will have a very different experience. People further into their transition will have a different experience.  Also, I identify as genderqueer, which is a complicating factor that I don't completely know how to make sense of. My dysphoric feelings are pretty 'binary' in the sense that it's mostly being non-female that hurts me, rather than being non-androgynous. The one really non-binary moment of this thing is the blues song, which is kind of a celebration of gender non-conformity and embrace of a masculine trait (my voice).  For people curious about the state of my gender situation, I'll just say for now that I'm still figuring it out. But enough about me, let's talk about me.
